stories.story: I remember the day I won my first big civil rights case. The courtroom was packed, and as the verdict was read, I felt a wave of relief and pride. My mentor squeezed my hand, and I saw tears in the eyes of the family I represented. That moment reminded me why I became a lawyer—to stand up for those who need it most. We celebrated with coffee and laughter in the courthouse lobby.

There was a day, years ago, when I won an important case. The courtroom was full, and I felt proud. My mentor was there, and the family I helped was grateful. We celebrated together. That memory keeps me going.
I remember winning a case—a big one. The courtroom was crowded. My mentor was there. The family thanked me. We celebrated.
There was a day, a case, a courtroom. My mentor, a family. We won. I remember feeling proud.
A case. Courtroom. Mentor. Family. We won.
